Graphical abstract Mn-Ce mixed oxides catalysts with different Mn/Ce molar ratio were prepared and used in the oxidation of primary amines to corresponding nitriles. The formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution between CeO2 and MnOx can greatly reduce the formation energy of oxygen defects and facilitate the mobility of oxygen species from the bulk to the surface, this leads to the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample showing the best catalytic performance. Mn-Ce mixed oxides, synthesized by co-impregnation method, have been used in the catalytic oxidation of primary amines to corresponding nitriles. The effects of Mn/Ce molar ratio on the structure and catalytic properties were investigated, and the results showed the MnxCe1-xOs mixed oxides exhibited higher catalytic activity than MnOx or CeO2. It was found that favorable selectivity and the best conversions for benzylic, heterocyclic, and aliphatic primary amines were obtained when the Mn/Ce atomic mole ratio was 2:1 (denoted as Mn0.67Ce0.33Os). These materials have been investigated using XRD, FT-IR, SEM, HRTEM, XPS, DR-UV–vis, H2-TPR, and EPR techniques. XRD results showed that the samples did not appear any diffraction of manganese oxides. SEM images showed that the nanoparticles of the mixed oxides can be uniformly distributed than MnOx or CeO2. HRTEM micrographs exhibited that Mn-Ce mixed oxides were all exposed (111) and (220) planes corresponding to CeO2, and Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst had the highest mutual solubility, thus this catalyst could have the stronger interaction than other Mn-Ce mixed oxides, which was in accordance with XPS, H2-TPR, and EPR analysis. XPS studies confirmed that the highest concentration of Ce3+ was obtained at the surface of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample, this situation provides a basis for the formation and stabilization of oxygen vacancies, and it is beneficial for oxidation reaction, which is in consistent with DR-UV–vis results. In addition, XPS data also showed that Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample provided the most adsorbed oxygen species, this suggested that the mobility and availability of the active oxygen species were enhanced. This conclusion also can be drawn from H2-TPR analysis. EPR studies further supported the formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution. Based on the above analysis, the excellent catalytic performance should be attributed to the formation of a solid solution with the incorporation of Mnx+ into the CeO2 cubic fluorite lattice, this reduces the formation energy of oxygen vacancies and enhances the mobility of active oxygen species from the bulk to the catalyst surface. Keywords Mn-Ce mixed oxides Solid solution Oxidation of amines Synergistic effects 1 Introduction Nitriles are important industrial intermediates, used to produce various polymers [1]. Nitriles are generally prepared by either nucleophilic substitution of halogenated hydrocarbon with cyanide ions, ammonia oxidation, or the Sandmeyer reaction [2]. These traditional methods usually require dangerous chemical reagents and stringent reaction conditions. This has motivated the exploration of new strategies to produce these commodities. Various methods have been developed for the synthesis of nitrile derivatives, the most direct of which is aerobic oxidation of amines [3]. Recently, the conversion of amines to nitriles has attracted the attention of researchers, several favorable results have been obtained. Metal-based oxidants [4] and noble metal catalysts such as Ru [5,6] and Au [7] have been reported, these processes often lead to the production of wastes. Although the addition of noble metal can improve the reaction activity, their high costs may limit their application. It is more reasonable to use molecular oxygen as sole oxidant from the consideration of green and sustainable chemistry [8]. A redox transformation between Ce3+ and Ce4+ in ceria and the high mobility of absorbed oxygen enables the formation of oxygen vacancies [9]. This promotes the activation and transportation of oxygen species, and leads to the high oxygen storage capacity of ceria [10]. Many reports have shown that adding a second metal to the ceria can effectively improve its activity in oxidation reactions [11,12]. The incorporation of manganese has been shown to improve the thermal stability as well as redox properties due to the formation of an efficient redox couple [13]. Synergistic interactions between MnOx and CeO2 can supply more active oxygen species [14], making Mn-Ce mixed oxides very attractive in various catalytic applications, such as hydrocarbons oxidation, combustion of volatile organic compounds and CO oxidation [14–16]. Herein, we have synthesized Mn-Ce mixed oxides catalysts, as well as the singular oxides via a co-impregnation method. We have investigated their catalytic performances for the oxidation of benzylamine, and obtained the most active catalyst Mn0.67Ce0.33Ox. This catalyst has achieved excellent catalytic results in the oxidation of several kinds of amines to corresponding nitriles. As far as we all know, it is the first time to report the aerobic oxidation of primary amines into corresponding nitriles over Mn-Ce mixed oxides. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Ce (NO3)3·6H2O, Mn (CH3COO)2·4H2O, and Na2CO3, were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Mn-Ce mixed oxides with different Mn/Ce mole ratios were prepared (respectively as 1:2, 1:1 and 2:1) through a modified co-impregnation method [11,17]. In a typical procedure, a certain amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O was dissolved in 20ml H2O and titrated to pH 10 with 1M Na2CO3, and the solution was stirred at room temperature for 40min. The resulting solids were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at 110°C for 12h. The catalysts were then calcined at 500°C for 5h. The acquired materials labeled as MnxCe1-xOs (where x represents the Mn/(Mn+Ce) atomic mole ratio), MnOx and CeO2 were synthesized by the same procedure. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The morphologies of the obtained mixed oxides, MnOx and CeO2 were examined by transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) (JEM-2100) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JSM-7600F). The crystalline aspects of the catalysts were studied by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/max 2500/PC). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a K-Alpha-surface Analysis system with X-Ray Monochromatisation. Fourier Transformed-Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) samples were obtained on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. DR-UV–vis measurements were performed on a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrophotometer in the 200–800nm regions. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of catalysts was conducted in a programmable tube furnace equipped with a MKS gas analyzer coupled with a quadrupole mass selective detector. In a typical experiment, 30mg of materials was packed in a quartz tube reactor mounted into the tube furnace, which was then heated from room temperature to 850°C with a heating ramp rate of 10°C/min. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were conducted on a Bruker (EMX-10/12) spectrometer, all the EPR spectra were recorded at 298K. 2.3 Catalyst test Aerobic oxidations of primary amines were carried out in a 100ml stainless steel intermittent reactor. Typically, amines (0.5ml), acetonitrile (5ml), and catalyst (50mg) were placed into the reactor, successively. The reactor was filled with O2 to replace the air for three times and kept the constant 2MPa O2 pressure. The reaction was initiated by immersing the reactor in the oil bath kept at the reaction temperature, then the reaction was carried out for the required time with constantly stirring (stirring rate: 800r/min). After reaction, the reactor was placed in cold water immediately to stop the reaction, and the products were identified by a standardized gas chromatograph (GC 9560) with a SE-54 capillary column. For recycled test, the used catalyst was washed with ethanol, followed by drying at 80°C, and then subjected to the reaction under the same conditions. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Optimization of reaction conditions The oxidation of benzylamine was chosen as a model reaction to determine the optimal reaction conditions (Table 1 ). Firstly, the reactions were performed over various catalysts in acetonitrile solvent (Table 1, entries 1–5). Mn0.67Ce0.33Os gave the highest conversion and 100% benzonitrile selectivity with 0.5h (Table 1, entry 5). In addition, both the MnOx and CeO2 exhibited poor activity on benzylamine even with 1h (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). Higher conversion was observed using oxygen as oxidant than air (Table 1, entry 6). Then the reactions were performed by Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst using different solvents (Table 1, entries 7–9), acetonitrile emerged as the best solvent. Because the production of by-product is favored at higher temperature and oxygen pressure (Table 1, entries 10–13), the reaction was carried out at relatively lower temperature (110°C) and 2Mpa pressure of oxygen. To testify the reaction mechanism, several experiments were carried out in the presence of radical inhibitor or without catalyst or using nitrogen instead of oxygen, they all gave poor conversion (Table 1, entries 14–16). Hence, the optimal reaction conditions were obtained as follows: Mn0.67Ce0.33Os as catalyst, acetonitrile as solvent, 110°C, 2Mpa O2. Next, we performed the rest of our study under these conditions. 3.2 Catalytic activity measurements Table 2 shows the oxidation of activated and non-activated amines to nitriles with molecular oxygen on Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst. The oxidations of heterocyclic and benzylic amines are faster than aliphatic amines. In a typical test, 30min reaction time for benzylic amines shows 81% yield, while 8h for n-hexylamine shows 94% yield (Table 2, entries 1 and 7). These results could be due to the lack of active groups attached to NH2 for the n-hexylamine. To determine the reusability of catalyst, the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst was reused five times for the oxidation of benzylamine, where no decrease in activity was found (Table 2, entry 2). 3h for 2-thiophene methylamine exhibited 89.1% yield and 3h for 2-furfuryl amine showed 51.2% yield, as the electronegativity of the oxygen atom was greater than that of the sulfur atom (Table 2, entries 5 and 6). Benzylic amines bearing electron-withdrawing substituents are oxidized rather slowly than benzylic amines without any substituent (Table 2, entries 4 and 1), while benzylic amines with electron-donating group are opposite (Table 2, entry 3). As can be seen from Table 3 , it takes up to 8h for the conversion of cyclohexylmethanamine to reach 98%, which was due to the presence of larger steric hindrance and the lack of active groups attached to NH2. However, when the reaction time is more than 5h, a small number of by-products for cyclohexanecarbaldehyde were found. Therefore, we propose possible reaction pathways for the oxidation of cyclohexylmethanamine (Scheme 1 ). An imine intermediate (C6H11CHNH) is formed via the oxidative dehydrogenation of cyclohexylmethanamine [1,3,6,18,19]. The unstable imine intermediate dehydrogenates rapidly and generates water under aerobic conditions [20,21]. With the extension of the reaction time and the formation of water, the hydrolysis of this unstable intermediate began to occur and form the cyclohexanecarbaldehyde by release of NH3 [20]. The generated water and released NH3 have been detected by water test paper and hydrochloric acid respectively. 3.3 Characterization of Mn-Ce mixed oxides Fig. 1 shows XRD diffraction patterns of MnOx, CeO2 and Mn-Ce mixed oxides catalysts. In the case of MnOx, the diffraction peaks at 2θ=23.2°, 33.0°, 38.2°, 49.4°, 55.2° and 65.8° are attributed to Mn2O3 (JCPDS: 24-0508). For CeOx, the intensive and sharp diffraction patterns at 2θ=28.4°, 33.0°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.4°, 76.7° and 79.1° clearly certify the existence of cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 (JCPDS: 65-5923). In the Mn-Ce mixed oxides, the (111), (200), (220) and (311) reflections belonging to CeO2 are observed. This discovery reveals that manganese oxide is dispersed into CeO2 lattice. The diffractions of the CeO2 become wider after the addition of Mn, which indicates that the Mn-Ce mixed oxides may contain smaller sized crystallites [22]. This is evidenced by the estimated crystallite size with the Scherrer Equation (Table 4 ). The diffraction patterns of CeO2 in the MnxCe1-xOs catalyst are slightly shifted to higher values compared with pure CeO2 (as shown in Fig. 1B), which further illustrates that part of Mn species enter into the cubic fluorite structure of CeO2 and form the MnxCe1-xOs solid solution [23,24]. This shift can be due to the contraction of the monomer after the incorporation of Mnx+ into CeO2 lattice, as the ionic radius of Mnx+ (Mn4+: 0.053nm; Mn3+: 0.065nm; Mn2+: 0.083nm) are smaller than that of Cex+(Ce4+: 0.097nm; Ce3+: 0.114nm). Due to the similarity of their structures, Ce4+ are easily replaced by Mnx+ in the cubic fluorite structure [25], and the incorporation of smaller cations can lead to a decrease in the lattice parameters of cerium oxides [26]. The lattice parameters of all the Mn-Ce samples are smaller than those of cerium oxides (Table 4), which further proves that the Mnx+ have been doped into the ceria lattice [27,28]. The vibrational frequency of the metal-oxygen bonds is sensitive due to the presence of the dopant species. Therefore, FT-IR can be used to prove the formation of doped oxides [29]. Fig. 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of MnOx, CeO2 and Mn-Ce mixed oxides from 4000 to 400cm−1. There is an obvious adsorption peak at 568cm−1 for CeO2, which can be due to the stretching vibration of the CeOCe bond [30]. Interestingly, when Mn is doped into the CeO2 lattice, the position of this peak for Mn0.67Ce0.33Os and Mn0.5Ce0.5Os samples shifts to the lower wavenumber (559cm−1) due to the formation of MnxCe1-xOs solid solution [9]. The adsorption for MnOx showed an obvious peak at 666cm−1, which can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the Mn-O-Mn bond [31,32]. The disappearance of this peak in the Mn-Ce mixed oxides clearly demonstrates that the manganese ions are well dissolved into the CeO2 lattice, which is consistent with the XRD results. The broad adsorption peak at about 3400cm−1 represents the stretching vibration of the OH bond of adsorbed water molecules. As can be seen from Fig. 2(e), the adsorption peak at 1600cm−1 is due to the H2O bending vibrations [33], 1322cm−1 is the characteristic peak of NO3 − derived from Ce(NO3)3·6H2O [25], 1050cm−1 is attributed to the formation of “carbonate-like” species on the CeO2 surface [30,33], 855cm−1 is assigned to the CO3 2− bending vibrations [34]. Additional band at 723cm−1 can be attributed to the bending vibrations of the CH bond [33]. Where the weaken peaks around 1700–700cm−1 in Mn-Ce mixed oxides are the same as CeO2 Fig. 3 shows the typical SEM and HRTEM images of the MnOx, CeO2 and Mn-Ce mixed oxides. The SEM figures show that the morphology of the samples change after the manganese ion was incorporated during the synthesis. Fig. 3a shows the oblong structure of manganese oxide with an average particle diameter of about 100nm. As can be seen from Fig. 3b–d, some oblong particle of ca.100nm are also evidently inlaid into the CeO2 crystal, the morphology of the samples can be clearly defined, and are uniformly distributed than MnOx or CeO2 (Fig. 3e). This can be supported by the previous literature [35]. Fig. 3g–i show the HRTEM micrographs of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os, Mn0.5Ce0.5Os and Mn0.33Ce0.67Os catalysts, respectively. Obviously, Mn0.67Ce0.33Os (Fig. 3g) shows smaller particle size than pure CeO2 (Fig. 3j), which can be due to the incorporation of Mnx+ inhibits the growth of CeO2 lattice [25,36]. Moreover, no separate MnOx phase is found from Fig. 3g–i, this further testify that the dopant Mnx+ has entered the CeO2 lattice [16]. Correspondingly, the (111) and (220) planes corresponding to CeO2 can be found through measuring the lattice fringes [14], it is consistent with the XRD data. Meanwhile, it is worthy to point out that there is no dislocation among the adjacent nanoparticles in Fig. 3g. This indicates that Mn0.67Ce0.33Os can obtain the strongest interaction than Mn0.5Ce0.5Os (Fig. 3h) or Mn0.33Ce0.67Os (Fig. 3i) due to the highest mutual solubility, which is in consistent with XPS, H2-TPR, and EPR data. Fig. 3f shows pure MnOx is mainly covered by (222) planes assigned to Mn2O3 [24]. Fig. 3j exhibits the CeO2 is mainly enclosed by (111) planes [14]. The XPS of Mn 2p, Ce 3d and O 1s of Mn-Ce mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4A, the O 1s spectrum with a shoulder peak is very broad and asymmetrical, this may be due to the superposition of various oxygen species. The peak at a binding energy of about 528eV is corresponding to lattice oxygen atoms (O2−; denoted as Olatt), comprised of a subset peak at 530eV ascribed to adsorbed oxygen species (O2−, O2 2−, O−, denoted as Oads). Adsorbed water, hydroxyl or carbonate species (denoted as Osur) are assigned to the O1s subset peak at 532eV [37,38]. The presence of surface water, hydroxyl, and carbonate species is also supported by FT-IR measurement. Adsorbed oxygen species (Oads) from defective sites with unsaturated structures are significantly important in the process of catalytic oxidation [16,39,40]. Table 5 shows the contents of Oads for the Mn-Ce composite catalysts. The Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample possesses the most adsorbed oxygen species. This suggests that the mobility and availability of the surface-adsorbed oxygen species are enhanced due to the synergistic effect between MnOx and CeO2. It is worthy to note that there is a shift of O 1s peaks (Table 5) to lower binding energy (BE) values than CeO2 (528.9, 531.9, and 533.5eV) [12], which can be caused by the addition of lower valence of manganese into the CeO2 lattice. These results show that there are more oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl groups on the surface of Mn-Ce mixed oxides than that of pure MnOx or CeO2 [9]. The sufficient oxygen vacancies can effectively absorb O2 from the environment and form the surface-active oxygen species, which can play an important role in catalytic oxidation of amines. Mn 2p XPS of Mn-Ce mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 4B. Mn 2p3/2 spectrum with a broad shoulder peak may imply the coexistence of Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+ species on the surface of catalysts [24]. For MnOx, the Mn 2p3/2 peak at a binding energy of about 643.8, 641.5, and 640.2eV corresponding to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+, respectively [41]. There is a shift of Mn 2p3/2 peak to the lower binding energy (643.1–643.5, 641.0–641.3 and 639.4–639.6eV) for MnxCe1-xOs catalysts comparing with MnOx, which can be due to the strong synergistic effect between MnOx and CeO2 [42]. The binding energy of Mn4+ in Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst is considerably higher than other mixed oxides, which also indicates the existence of a strong interaction between MnOx and CeO2 in Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst [22]. Ce 3d XPS of Mn-Ce mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 4C. The curves of Ce 3d XPS spectra were split into eight peaks. The six peaks marked by V, V″, V‴, U, U″, and U‴ refer to Ce4+, and the remaining two peaks marked by V′ and U′ are characteristic of Ce3+ [41,43]. Thus, we can observe that Ce3+ and Ce4+ species coexist in the Mn-Ce composites, and the concentration of Ce3+ at the surface of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os, Mn0.5Ce0.5Os and Mn0.33Ce0.67Os samples are ca. 13.8%, 11.0%, and 9.4% respectively. Interestingly, the addition of Mn leads to the gradual enhancement in the concentration of Ce3+, and the doping of Mn has a significant effect on the redox properties of the catalysts. Among these Mn-Ce mixed oxides, the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os exhibits the highest concentration of Ce3+, which shows a strong interaction between the MnOx and CeO2 exists in the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os. We believe that the reason why Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst contains the highest numbers of adsorption oxygen species is that the CeO2 can generate adsorption oxygen species through the release of lattice oxygen under anoxic conditions. In addition, the Ce4+ ↔Ce3+ redox can provide the basis for the formation and stabilization of oxygen vacancies in Mn-Ce mixed oxides as Kröger-Vink equation clarifies [44] (Fig. 5 ). Where Ce4+, O, Ce3+, and VO ·· refers to Ce4+ on a lattice site of ceria, an oxygen atom on an oxygen lattice site, Ce3+ with a single negative charge in the lattice site of ceria, and oxygen vacancy with double positive charge, respectively. DR-UV–vis study is a very sensitive probe for identification and characterization of various oxidation states and the presence of defects formed in the lattice [16,45]. The DR-UV–vis spectra of the CeO2 and Mn-Ce mixed oxides are shown in Fig. 6 (A) and (B), respectively. As can be seen from Fig. 6(A), four narrow bands are found in the range of 250–350nm, which can be attributed to the CeO2 crystallites [46], and these bands are assigned to localized O-Ce charge transfer transitions involving a number of surface Ce4+ ions [47]. In addition, a split of absorption of pure CeO2 and Mn-Ce mixed oxides is observed prominently in the UV region (200–250nm) corresponding to the 4f-5d transitions for the isolated Ce3+ ions on the surface or in the matrices of samples [46]. The band at 336nm in DR spectra of CeO2 is ascribed to inter band transitions [48]. However, corresponding bands for Mn-Ce mixed oxides are shifted to higher wavelength compared with pure CeO2 (Fig. 6B), Obviously, Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst exhibited the highest shift (363nm), this shift can be attributed to the increase in the content of Ce3+ due to the doping of Mn [49]. Thus the ratio of Ce3+ in Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample is the highest among the mixed oxides [50], this can improve the oxygen storage capacity of ceria to some extent [10]. By comparing the two figures, we can observe that the absorption bands of Mn-Ce mixed oxides in the range of 250–350nm increase highly and the band of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os is the strongest, which indicates the presence of the most defects in the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os [16]. Further, the Mn-Ce mixed oxides exhibit three broad bands in the visible region. The former absorption around 420nm is associated to Mn4+ [51]. The second weak absorption near 605nm can be ascribed to the 6A1 → 4T1 forbidden d-d transition of Mn2+ [52]. The last absorption band around 720–730nm is assigned to characteristic absorption of Mn3+ [52]. Obviously, the result obtained from DR-UV–vis study is in accordance with XPS result. To detect the reduction properties of MnOx, CeO2, and Mn-Ce mixed oxides, H2-TPR curves of all the catalysts were recorded in Fig. 7 . As shown in Fig. 7, CeO2 shows two reduction peaks at around 514 and 854°C. The first is ascribed to the reduction of oxygen species on the surface of CeO2, and the second is corresponded to the oxygen species in the bulk CeO2 [53,54]. MnOx exhibits two strong reduction peaks at about 297 and 412°C, the former is attributed to the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and the latter is assigned to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO, respectively [55]. The result is consistent with XRD data. Mn-Ce mixed oxides exhibit three reduction peaks. It is easy to acknowledge that the two low-temperature peaks are ascribed to the two-step reduction of Mn2O3 according to the reduction characteristics of MnOx. At the same time, the reduction reaction of CeO2 occurred. The first reduction peak at around 500°C disappeared, which may overlap with the second reduction peak of MnOx. It means that the first reduction temperature of CeO2 has reduced to ca. 300°C, which may be caused by the synergistic effect between MnOx and CeO2. In addition, the second reduction peak for CeO2 has been dropped from original ca. 854 to 771, 757 and 720°C with the Mn content increasing. This phenomenon also appears in MnOx, the reduction temperature of MnOx is also reduced. In addition, it is worthy to note that the reduction temperature are lower and the H2 consumption are higher of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst than other studied MnxCe1-xOs catalysts (Mn0.5Ce0.5Os, Mn0.33Ce0.67Os). Therefore, the lower reduction temperature can clearly illustrate that the formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution with MnOCe bonds and the large amount of surface defects (such as oxygen vacancies) can be easier to induce, which can accelerate the mobility of oxygen species [56]. The higher H2 consumption can clearly demonstrate that a large number of reactive oxygen species. Therefore, Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst has showed the best performance in catalytic oxidation of amines among the three catalysts. The formation of Mn-Ce solid solution with MnOCe bonds also can be observed and confirmed by EPR spectra. Fig. 8 shows the EPR spectra of the series of Mn-Ce mixed oxides recorded at 298K. The g and hyperfine values (g=2.0005 and A Mn =92.6G, g=2.0003 and A Mn =92.6G, and g=2.000 and A Mn =92.6G for Mn0.67Ce0.33Os, Mn0.5Ce0.5Os, and Mn0.33Ce0.67Os, respectively) are consistent with Mn2+ [23]. The concentration of Mn2+ is positively correlated with the intensity of the ordinate in Fig. 8. Interestingly, Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst with the highest content of Mn were detected with the lowest content of Mn2+, that is because the Mn2+ in the gap and the surface locations move to the CeO2 lattice [23]. These results illustrate that the Mn species in the Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst are farther integrated into the CeO2 matrix compared with Mn0.5Ce0.5Os and Mn0.33Ce067Os samples. This further supports the formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution. 3.4 Mechanism investigation Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst have exhibited higher catalytic activity for the aerobic oxidation of aromatic, heterocyclic and aliphatic amines with CH2NH2 functional groups with oxygen molecule as the sole oxidant, which has achieved high yields to nitriles. We proposed a possible reaction mechanism for the aerobic oxidation of primary amines into corresponding nitriles over Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst based on the experimental results and literature (Scheme 2 ). Several experiments were carried out (including the detection of water and NH3 as described above) to deeply understand the mechanism for the oxidation of primary amines to nitriles (Table 1, entries 14–16). In the presence of 2, 6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (a radical inhibitor), the oxidation reaction did not occur (Table 1, entry 14). Put it another way, the nitriles derived from the unstable RCH=NH intermediate that involved a radical pathway. The mechanism for the formation of this RCH=NH intermediate through transfer two electrons, an α C-H proton, and an α N-H proton (Scheme 3 ) is similar to that reported in previous literatures [3,19]. The transferred electrons caused the reduction of Mn center or Ce center (Mn4+ →Mn3+ →Mn2+ or Ce4+ →Ce3+), and the change of valence state caused the release of active oxygen species from the catalyst surface [57], which can promote the oxidation ability. This also was supported by the observation that the reaction almost did not occur in the absence of the catalyst (Table 1, entry 15). The surface active oxygen species (O2−, O2 2−, O−) can combine with protons (H+) and electrons (e−) released in this catalytic cycle to generate water (the O2− only need to combine with protons H+) [58], which can accelerate the oxidation of Mn center or Ce center. The supply oxygen from the external environment plays a key role in this catalytic cycle, because the lost active oxygen species need to be replenished by the oxygen from the external environment with reoxidized the Mn center or Ce center (Mn2+ →Mn3+ →Mn4+ or Ce3+ →Ce4+) [19]. This can be supported that the reaction rate was diminished when the reactor was filled with nitrogen instead of oxygen (Table 1, entry 16). Additionally, in Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution, Ce4+ species were replaced by Mn x+ ones to release adsorbed oxygen (O2 −, O2 2−, O−) to balance the charge. The Ce4+ ↔Ce3+ redox process can provide the basis for the formation of oxygen defects, which can offer additional active oxygen species. These active oxygen species can be transferred to the surface of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution through oxygen defects to directly oxidize adsorbed amines. It is worthy to note that the formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution between CeO2 and MnOx can greatly reduce the formation energy of oxygen defects, and then improve the activity of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst. We can conclude that the formation of solid solutions is significantly important in aerobic oxidation of primary amines to nitriles. 4 Conclusions A series of Mn-Ce mixed oxides, pure MnOx, and CeO2 were prepared by a co-impregnation method and used in the aerobic oxidation of primary amines to the corresponding nitriles, which has achieved favorable conversion and selectivity. Mn-Ce mixed oxides exhibited better catalytic activity than MnOx or CeO2. When the mole ratio of Mn/Ce was 2:1, the catalytic activity of Mn-Ce mixed oxides showed the best catalytic performance, this catalyst can be used for five times without any loss of activity. XRD, FT-IR, HRTEM, XPS, H2-TPR, and EPR results have determined that the formation of a solid solution plays a decisive role in catalytic oxidation of amines. This study provides a simple tactic to obtain Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution catalyst and can effectively catalyze primary amines to corresponding nitriles at mild conditions. We have proposed a possible reaction mechanism for this complex system. Further research on the catalytic application of these mixed oxides is still in progress. coredata.dc:description: Mn-Ce mixed oxides, synthesized by co-impregnation method, have been used in the catalytic oxidation of primary amines to corresponding nitriles. The effects of Mn/Ce molar ratio on the structure and catalytic properties were investigated, and the results showed the MnxCe1-xOs mixed oxides exhibited higher catalytic activity than MnOx or CeO2. It was found that favorable selectivity and the best conversions for benzylic, heterocyclic, and aliphatic primary amines were obtained when the Mn/Ce atomic mole ratio was 2:1 (denoted as Mn0.67Ce0.33Os). These materials have been investigated using XRD, FT-IR, SEM, HRTEM, XPS, DR-UV–vis, H2-TPR, and EPR techniques. XRD results showed that the samples did not appear any diffraction of manganese oxides. SEM images showed that the nanoparticles of the mixed oxides can be uniformly distributed than MnOx or CeO2. HRTEM micrographs exhibited that Mn-Ce mixed oxides were all exposed (111) and (220) planes corresponding to CeO2, and Mn0.67Ce0.33Os catalyst had the highest mutual solubility, thus this catalyst could have the stronger interaction than other Mn-Ce mixed oxides, which was in accordance with XPS, H2-TPR, and EPR analysis. XPS studies confirmed that the highest concentration of Ce3+ was obtained at the surface of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample, this situation provides a basis for the formation and stabilization of oxygen vacancies, and it is beneficial for oxidation reaction, which is in consistent with DR-UV–vis results. In addition, XPS data also showed that Mn0.67Ce0.33Os sample provided the most adsorbed oxygen species, this suggested that the mobility and availability of the active oxygen species were enhanced. This conclusion also can be drawn from H2-TPR analysis. EPR studies further supported the formation of Mn0.67Ce0.33Os solid solution. Based on the above analysis, the excellent catalytic performance should be attributed to the formation of a solid solution with the incorporation of Mnx+ into the CeO2 cubic fluorite lattice, this reduces the formation energy of oxygen vacancies and enhances the mobility of active oxygen species from the bulk to the catalyst surface.
coredata.dc:title: Aerobic oxidation of primary amines into corresponding nitriles over MnxCe1-xOs catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method
